facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 291 of 1960 filed in Supreme Court by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 291 of 1960. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated October 21, 1955 of Andhra High Court at Guntur in Appeal against order No. 94 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated October 21, 1955, of the Andhra High Court at Guntur in Appeal against order No. 94 of 1952.

facts.text: Insolvency proceedings taken against the firm of T. A. Doshi, Bombay by its creditors on original side of Bombay High Court and in District Court, Bellary.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave arises out of insolvency proceedings taken against the firm of T. A. Doshi, Bombay  hereinafter called the firm  by its creditors on the original side of the Bombay High Court, as well as in the District Court, Bellary.

facts.text: Petition I. P. No. 2 of 1950 presented in District Court, Bellary on January 25, 1950 by some creditors for adjudicating the firm insolvent.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that on January 25, 1950, an replication was presented  I. P. No. 2 of 1950  in e District Court, Bellary, by some of the creditors of the firm for adjudicating the firm as insolvent,

facts.text: Order of adjudication passed by District Court, Bellary on December 13, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: and on December 13, 1950, an order of adjudication was passed. Pending the adjudication proceedings, the District Court appointed the Official Receiver as interim Receiver

facts.text: Pending adjudication, District Court appointed Official Receiver as interim Receiver, who took possession of goods in transit to Bombay and disposed of them under court orders, sale-proceeds deposited in court.

anchor.surface_text: Pending the adjudication proceedings, the District Court appointed the Official Receiver as interim Receiver at the instance of the petitioning creditors. The Receiver was authorised to take possession of certain goods alleged to belong to the insolvent which were then in transit to Bombay. Accordingly, the Receiver took possession of the said goods and under the orders of the Court, disposed of them. The sale-proceeds were then deposited in companyrt.

facts.text: Respondents claimed entitlement to part of deposited money because Railway Receipt for goods was made over to them by insolvent for consideration.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon, the respondents moved the District Court and claimed that they were entitled to a part of the money deposited by the Official Receiver, because the Railway Receipt in respect of the goods which had been sold by the Receiver had been made over to them by the insolvent for companysideration.

facts.text: Respondents permitted to withdraw amount on April 6, 1950 on giving security and undertaking to redeposit with 6% interest when called upon.

anchor.surface_text: In accordance with this order, the respondents withdrew the money on April 6, 1950. The claim made by the respondents in this way still remains to be tried though they withdrew the amount as far back as 6-4-50.

facts.text: Insolvency petition I. P. No. 52 of 1950 filed in Bombay High Court on April 14, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: similar proceedings had already been taken against the firm by some other creditors on the original side of the Bombay High Court on April 14, 1950,  I. P. No. 52 of 1950 .

facts.text: Adjudication order passed by Bombay High Court on April 17, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: On this application, an adjudication order was passed on April 17, 1950. As a result of this order of adjudication all the properties of the insolvent vested in the Official Assignee of Bombay.

facts.text: Official Assignee moved District Court Bellary with I. A. No. 183 of 1950 to stay proceedings and transfer assets.

anchor.surface_text: The Official Assignee then moved the District Court at Bellary  I. A. No. 183 of 1950 , and prayed that insolvency proceedings pending against the firm in that Court should be stayed and that all the assets and books of account,, belonging, to the insolvent should be transferred to Bombay.

facts.text: On December 13, 1950, District Court Bellary directed Official Receiver to move Bombay High Court to annul its adjudication order of April 17, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: On December 13, 1950, whilst making an order of adjudication, the District Court passed an order on the application made before it by the Official Assignee of Bombay. It directed its Official Receiver to move the Bombay High Court to annul the adjudication order made by it on April 17, 1950.

facts.text: Respondents preferred appeal against District Court order of December 13, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: This order was number challenged by the respon- dents by preferring an appeal against it.

facts.text: Official Receiver took no action for a long time on direction to move Bombay High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Though the District Court had directed the Official Receiver to move Bombay High Court, numberaction was taken by him for along time

facts.text: Official Assignee filed I. A. No. 171 of 1951 on October 15, 1951 in District Court Bellary to direct deposit and transfer of assets.

anchor.surface_text: and so, the Official Assignee had to file another application before the Distt. Court  I. A. No. 171 of 1951  on October 15, 1951. By this application, the Official Assignee brought it to the numberice of the Court that the Official Receiver had taken numberaction

facts.text: Official Receiver moved Bombay High Court for annulment, which declined and directed continuance of proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: Meanwhile, the Official Receiver moved the Bombay High Court for annulment of the adjudication order already passed by it. The High Court declined to annul its adjudication order and directed the companytinuance of the insolvency proceedings before it

facts.text: District Court Bellary directed Official Receiver to transmit accounts and deposits, and respondents to refund withdrawn amount with 6% interest for transfer to Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: Having regard to the fact that the Bombay, High Court had declined to annul its adjudication order, the District Court took the view that the application made by the Official Assignee should be allowed. It, therefore, directed the Official Receiver to transmit all the accounts and deposits lying in companyrt and called upon the respondents to refund the amounts drawn by them on furnishing security with interest 6 per annum,

facts.text: Respondents appealed District Court order to High Court of Andhra Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: This order was challenged by the respondents by preferring an appeal before the High Court of Andhra Pradesh.

facts.text: Andhra High Court allowed respondents' appeal, held Official Assignee's application did not satisfy section 77 of Provincial Insolvency Act, convenient to administer at Kurnool.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has allowed the appeal. It has held that the application made by the Official Assignee did number satisfy the requirements of section 77 of the Provincial Insolvency Act and that, on the whole, it would be more companyvenient. that the estate of the insolvent should be administered by the District Court at Kurnool

facts.text: Official Assignee of Bombay appealed to Supreme Court against Andhra High Court decision.

anchor.surface_text: It is against this decision of the High Court that the Official Assignee  hereinafter called the appellant  has companye to this Court.

facts.text: Bombay High Court adjudication order relates back to March 14, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Applying this principle, it would follow that the adjudication order passed by the Bombay High Court on April 17, 1950, on the insolvency petition filed before it goes back number only to the date on which the said petition was presented, viz, April 14, 1950, but to the earliest act of insolvency within three months prior to the said presentation which is March 14, 1950.

facts.text: Bellary District Court adjudication order relates back to January 25, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: the order of adjudication passed by the District Court on December 13, 1950, will relate back to January 25, 1950 when the petition was presented in the said Court.

facts.text: Supreme Court held property of insolvent vested in Official Assignee of Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the property of the insolvent vests in the Official Assignee by virtue of the operation of s. 17 of the Presidency Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court set aside Andhra High Court order and restored District Court order with modification regarding respondents' withdrawn amount.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal is allowed, the order passed by the High Court is set aside and that of the District Court restored with the modification in respect of the amount withdrawn by the respondents, as indicated above.

facts.text: Respondents' claim remains to be tried.

anchor.surface_text: The claim made by the respondents in this way still remains to be tried though they withdrew the amount as far back as 6-4-50.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated October 21, 1955, of the Andhra High Court at Guntur in Appeal against order No. 94 of 1952.

Sec. 17 of the Presidency Act provides, inter alia, that on the making of an order of adjudication, the property of the insolvent wherever situate shall vest in the official assignee and shall become divisible among his creditors.

concepts.interpretation: Property of insolvent vests immediately in Official Assignee upon making of adjudication order; subsequent adjudication under Provincial Act does not divest it due to statutory vesting.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 51 of the said Act it is provided, inter alia, that the insolvency of a debtor shall be deemed to have relation back to, and to commence at, (a) the time of the commission of the act of insolvency upon which an order of adjudication is made against him, or (b) if the insolvent is proved to have committed more acts of insolvency than one, the time of the first of the acts of insolvency proved to have been committed by the insolvent within three months next preceding the date of the presentation of the insolvency petition.

concepts.interpretation: Adjudication order relates back to earliest act of insolvency within three months prior to petition presentation.

issues.text: in whom does the property of the insolvent vest ?

anchor.surface_text: The first question which calls for our decision in this appeal is in whom does the property of the insolvent vest ? For deciding this question, the relevant provisions of the Provincial Insolvency Act and the Presidency Towns Insolvency Act have to be considered.

issues.text: whether the application made by the Official Assignee satisfies the requirements of section 77 of the Provincial Insolvency Act

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has allowed the appeal. It has held that the application made by the Official Assignee did not satisfy the requirements of section 77 of the Provincial Insolvency Act and that, on the whole, it would be more convenient that the estate of the insolvent should be administered by the District Court at Kurnool

issues.text: whether the earlier order was a final order and did amount to res judicata between the parties

anchor.surface_text: Dealing with this aspect of the matter, the High Court was inclined to take the view that the earlier order was not a final order and did not amount to res judicata between the parties.

anchor.surface_text: It observed that when, such an application is made before the Bombay High Court, the said Court will consider all the relevant facts and circumstances and decide whether it would be convenient for all concerned to allow the assets and effects of the insolvent to be administered at Bellary or at Bombay

arguments.claim: Doctrine of relation back has no application where property already vested in Official Assignee under prior adjudication; no divesting

anchor.surface_text: Section 17 provides for the vesting of the property on the making of the order of adjudication, and so, when the District Court at Bellary passed an adjudication order in the insolvency proceedings pending before it, s. 28  2  could number in law operate in respect of the insolvents property because the said property had by virtue of the statutory provisions contained in s. 17 of the Presidency Act already vested in the Official Assignee.

arguments.claim: Prior adjudication vests property in Official Assignee of first court; subsequent adjudication does not divest even if based on earlier acts of insolvency

anchor.surface_text: A similar question fell to be considered by the Madras High Court in The Official Assignee of Madras v. The Official Assignee of Rangoon ... held that where there are successive adjudications in insolvency by two Courts, all the property of the insolvent vests in the Official Assignee appointed by the Court in which the prior adjudication was made and it will number be divested from him by the subsequent adjudication of the other Court

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the property of the insolvent vests in the Official Assignee by virtue of the operation of s. 17 of the Presidency Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.17 PTIA causes immediate vesting upon adjudication order on Apr 17 1950; s.28(2) PIA cannot divest prior statutory vesting even if Bellary order relates back earlier via s.28(7); doctrine protects creditors but does not divest

holdings.text: Section 17 provides for the vesting of the property on the making of the order of adjudication, and so, when the District Court at Bellary passed an adjudication order in the insolvency proceedings pending before it, s. 28 (2) could not in law operate in respect of the insolvents property because the said property had by virtue of the statutory provisions contained in s. 17 of the Presidency Act already vested in the Official Assignee

anchor.surface_text: Section 17 provides for the vesting of the property on the making of the order of adjudication, and so, when the District Court at Bellary passed an adjudication order in the insolvency proceedings pending before it, s. 28 (2) could not in law operate in respect of the insolvents property because the said property had by virtue of the statutory provisions contained in s. 17 of the Presidency Act already vested in the Official Assignee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior vesting under PTIA s.17 is statutory and immediate; no provision in PIA for divesting; relation back under s.28(7) PIA/s.51 PTIA has no divesting effect

holdings.text: the doctrine of relation back prescribed by s. 28 7 has no application to cases where the insolvents property has already vested in the Official Assignee. Therefore, we must hold that the property of the firm has validly vested in the Official Assignee

anchor.surface_text: The doctrine of relating back on which s. 28 7 of the Provincial Act and s. 51 of the Presidency Act are based, could have no application in the present case because the vesting in the Official Assignee is the result of a statutory provision and so, in the absence of any provision in the Provincial Act for the divesting of the property which has already vested in the Official Assignee, it cannot be said that the doctrine of relating back has that effect.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Relation back intended for recovery from third parties, not divesting prior vesting; reconciles PTIA ss.17/51 with PIA ss.28(2)/(7); follows Madras HC precedent on successive adjudications

holdings.text: this view is substantially correct in so far as the construction of s. 77 is concerned. Section 77 lays down the procedure whereby one Court can make a request to another Court, and in that behalf it provides that considerations of decorum and courtesy require that the request should be made by the Court itself and not by its officers

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, this view is substantially correct in so far as the construction of s. 77 is concerned. Section 77 lays down the procedure whereby one Court can make a request to another Court, and in that behalf it provides that considerations of decorum and courtesy require that the request should be made by the Court itself and not by its officers.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.77 requires court order and letter of request for inter-court aid; officer's application alone insufficient due to decorum

holdings.text: the said application does not purport to have been made and is, in fact, and, in law, not made under s. 77 [...] the principal object of the Official Assignee in making the subsequent application was to invite the attention of the Court to the failures of its officer to comply with the order already passed
holdings.reasoning_summary: Application was to enforce prior DC order (Dec 13 1950) which became operative after Bombay HC refusal to annul; not inter-court request under s.77

holdings.text: this view is erroneous. The said order was passed in proceedings to which the respondents were parties, and so far as the District Court was concerned,it dealt with the whole of the dispute then pending between the Official Assignee and the respondents. [...] the said order was complete and final

anchor.surface_text: Dealing with this aspect of the matter, the High Court was inclined to take the view that the earlier order was not a final order and did not amount to res judicata between the parties. In our opinion, this view is erroneous.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dec 13 1950 DC order fully disposed dispute between parties; conditional on Bombay HC decision which occurred, making it operative and binding as res judicata

holdings.text: we must proceed on the basis that the property of the firm has vested in the Official Assignee at Bombay and the Bombay High Court is entitled to deal with all matters arising in respect of the insolvency of the firm

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, in dealing with the present dispute, we must proceed on the basis that the property of the firm has vested in the Official Assignee at Bombay and the Bombay High Court is entitled to deal with all matters arising in respect of the insolvency of the firm.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from vesting under PTIA; principal court for administration

holdings.text: We do not propose to express any opinion on this point in the present appeal [...] It would, however, be open to the Bombay High Court to allow the dispute between the respondents and the Official Assignee to be tried by the Bellary Court if it came to the conclusion that it would be convenient, fair and just to adopt such a course
holdings.reasoning_summary: Declines to decide subsidiary claim venue; leaves to Bombay HC discretion on convenience

precedents.citation: The Official Assignee of Madras v. The Official Assignee of Rangoon by his Agent Subramania Aiyar I.L.R. 42 Mad. 121

anchor.surface_text: A similar question fell to be companysidered by the Madras High Court in The Official Assignee of Madras v. The Official Assignee of Rangoon by his Agent Subramania Aiyar 1 . Wallis, C. J., who delivered the judgment of the Court held that where there are successive adjudications in insolvency by two Courts, all the property of the insolvent vests in the Official Assignee appointed by the Court in which the prior adjudication was made and it will number be divested from him by the subsequent adjudication of the other Court, even if the later adjudication be based on acts of insolvency companymitted earlier in date than those upon which the prior adjudication I.L.R. 42 Mad. 121.

precedents.case_name: Official Assignee of Madras v Official Assignee of Rangoon
precedents.cited_proposition: where there are successive adjudications in insolvency by two Courts, all the property of the insolvent vests in the Official Assignee appointed by the Court in which the prior adjudication was made and it will not be divested from him by the subsequent adjudication of the other Court, even if the later adjudication be based on acts of insolvency committed earlier in date than those upon which the prior adjudication was made
precedents.cited_holding: the property shall vest in the Official Assignee is express, and there is no provision in the Act divesting the property so vested in that Official Assignee and transferring it to another Official Assignee under a later adjudication

King Co. 1 .  1  30 Cal. 542. The difficulty in accepting the companyclusion of the High Court

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; order of Andhra High Court set aside; order of District Court restored with modification granting respondents liberty to apply to Bombay High Court regarding trial of their claim and redeposit of withdrawn amount.
directions: Respondents liberty to apply to Bombay High Court within two months for dispute to be tried at Bellary District Court.
Bombay High Court may decide if amount withdrawn by respondents to be redeposited before or after disposal of dispute if plea accepted.
If no application within two months, respondents to redeposit entire amount with interest in Bellary Court for transfer to Bombay High Court.
If allowed by Bombay High Court, trial in District Court at Bellary, not Kurnool.

anchor.surface_text: Section 17 provides for the vesting of the property on the making of the order of adjudication, and so, when the District Court at Bellary passed an adjudication order in the insolvency proceedings pending before it, s. 28 (2) could not in law operate in respect of the insolvents property because the said property had by virtue of the statutory provisions contained in s. 17 of the Presidency Act already vested in the Official Assignee.

In the result, the appeal is allowed, the order passed by the High Court is set aside and that of the District Court restored with the modification in respect of the amount withdrawn by the respondents, a

anchor.surface_text: The doctrine of relating back on which s. 28 7 of the Provincial Act and s. 51 of the Presidency Act are based, could have no application in the present case because the vesting in the Official Assignee is the result of a statutory provision and so, in the absence of any provision in the Provincial Act for the divesting of the property which has already vested in the Official Assignee, it cannot be said that the doctrine of relating back has that effect.

In the result, the appeal is allowed, the order passed by the High Court is set aside and that of the District Court restored with the modification in respect of the amount withdrawn by the respondents, a

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, this view is substantially correct in so far as the construction of s. 77 is concerned. Section 77 lays down the procedure whereby one Court can make a request to another Court, and in that behalf it provides that considerations of decorum and courtesy require that the request should be made by the Court itself and not by its officers.

In the result, the appeal is allowed, the order passed by the High Court is set aside and that of the District Court restored with the modification in respect of the amount withdrawn by the respondents, a

h5 holds that the application was not made under s.77, directly addressing the issue of whether it satisfies s.77 requirements

anchor.surface_text: Dealing with this aspect of the matter, the High Court was inclined to take the view that the earlier order was not a final order and did not amount to res judicata between the parties. In our opinion, this view is erroneous.

In the result, the appeal is allowed, the order passed by the High Court is set aside and that of the District Court restored with the modification in respect of the amount withdrawn by the respondents, a

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, in dealing with the present dispute, we must proceed on the basis that the property of the firm has vested in the Official Assignee at Bombay and the Bombay High Court is entitled to deal with all matters arising in respect of the insolvency of the firm.

In the result, the appeal is allowed, the order passed by the High Court is set aside and that of the District Court restored with the modification in respect of the amount withdrawn by the respondents, a
